name: TheAtlantic
text: Early voting has long been the norm for Americans overseas. This year, they're poised to turn out in record numbers, reports @YasmeenSerhan: https://t.co/NXZLpsr43o

name: TheAtlantic
text: ‚ÄúI felt as though an ocular dial had been tweaked and the details of my life‚Äîobjects, surfaces, textures‚Äîbegan to intensify.‚Äù Oliver Munday on how reading Proust during the pandemic sharpened his perception: https://t.co/n3hpTo4gGv

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Ponyo." "Julie & Julia." "Unstoppable." "Addams Family Values." Everyone has their own list of "comfort movies," but @davidlsims turns to these 25 genre-spanning films again and again: https://t.co/5fAI4TSPkY

name: TheAtlantic
text: A former Detroit cop makes a living on YouTube filming America's worst neighborhoods. @clickclaimprize reports: https://t.co/H8pHX65mwh

name: TheAtlantic
text: Books by Ocean Vuong, Elizabeth Acevedo, Ben Lerner, and more bring poetic voice to works written in prose in this week's #TheAtlanticBooksBriefing. From @cray_kate: https://t.co/ZxhTk6O0sP

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The Supreme Court has transformed constitutional provisions for fighting racial segregation into instruments that preserve it," @LeahLitman writes: https://t.co/Z7zDvarOtn

name: TheAtlantic
text: Even just delaying COVID-19 infections will save lives. @sarahzhang reports on falling death rates for hospitalized patients: https://t.co/fyKFWcrHxI

name: TheAtlantic
text: ‚ÄúIt is unlikely to think that someone who was trained by Strom Thurmond would end up being like brothers with me, my father being a civil-rights activist.‚Äù @revdrbarber and @wilsonhartgrove tell @julieebeck how their friendship fuels their activism: https://t.co/wRGBxjWRIQ

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The Constitution was meant to foster a complex form of majority rule, not enable minority rule," George Thomas writes: https://t.co/FY03SEvxV0

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @TomMcTague: How Britain became an unwilling and exposed combatant in the US election‚Äîand why it might be time for London to heed JFK‚Äôs advice 60yrs on (sort of) and ask not what it can do for America, but what Britain must now do for itselfüëá https://t.co/yPh3XaJswn

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @prashantrao: If Britain is worried by Joe Biden, then perhaps its problems are bigger than it realizes? Read @TomMcTague for more https://t.co/5a6WZ5vzjY

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @JeffreyGoldberg: "Enabling sustained minority rule at the national level is not a feature of our constitutional design, but a perversion of it."
Read the whole article:
https://t.co/gspcyqgfLD

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @JohnGHendy: ‚ÄúI know why he exaggerates, because I exaggerate,‚Äù Manny said. ‚ÄúThey use his exaggerations, and they call it a lie.‚Äù https://t.co/ETmfE1AzdK via @russellberman

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @russellberman: There aren't a lot of voters in Levant, Maine, but there are a lot of Levants in America. And to offset his losses elsewhere on Tuesday, Trump will have to squeeze even more votes from the small, white communities that delivered him the presidency in 2016 https://t.co/uiLEapLoba

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @JeffreyGoldberg: "The virus‚Äôs most direct impact on the economy and the workforce has been strangely overlooked. It is killing workers, slowing them down, pushing them to take leave from their jobs, and causing them to drop out of the labor force...." -- @AnnieLowrey:
https://t.co/VuvRTt7jda

name: TheAtlantic
text: Related: In September, @LoriGottlieb1 advised a teenager whose mother was pressuring her to get better grades. https://t.co/NJjviXd8K0

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Dead workers, sick workers, disabled workers, workers forced out of the workforce: This is one of the virus‚Äôs worst legacies, and it proves that there is no saving the economy without saving the people who make it up," @AnnieLowrey writes: https://t.co/v2wbs2jvCe

name: TheAtlantic
text:
Donald Trump has suggested that he might fire Anthony Fauci after the election.

Trump shouldn‚Äôt be able to do this, @petermshane argued in April. ‚ÄúCongress should make sure that expert voices get heard.‚Äù https://t.co/eVaYSiel4N

name: TheAtlantic
text: The American election isn't just crucial for Americans. In many ways, it is an existential vote for Britain, too, @TomMcTague writes: https://t.co/h4VjNuoZve

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @LoriGottlieb1: ‚ÄúIf you want a relationship with the mother you have, you‚Äôre going to have to let go of the fantasy mother you wish she were."

This week ‚Å¶@TheAtlantic‚Å© : Forging an adult relationship with a problematic parent may involve some #grieving  https://t.co/8AYbKu6t0e

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @TomMcTague: Britain is holding its breath ahead of tomorrow's big day. But perhaps that itself shows there's something amiss. Time for Britain to grow up and... take control? My latest
https://t.co/hFuBwT8t9U

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: "Our electoral system was not built to withstand a sustained assault on its legitimacy." Read @bartongellman's latest: https://t.co/Agnun3y7iG

name: TheAtlantic
text:
We asked some of our editors which stories you should make sure to read before Election Day. Here are their top picks: 

1. President Trump may win or lose, but he will never concede, Barton Gellman writes. https://t.co/j3BIWMg4uy

name: TheAtlantic
text: 2. Trump may wage a war of disinformation if election results don‚Äôt go his way, McKay Coppins warns‚Äîand the ‚ÄúArmy for Trump‚Äù is gearing up to help by camping out at polling locations. https://t.co/wsk4i6tLer

name: TheAtlantic
text:
3. ‚ÄúDespite ample warning, the U.S. squandered every possible opportunity to control the coronavirus.‚Äù Ed Yong explains how the world‚Äôs most powerful country was brought to its knees. 
https://t.co/4RVexsBbSU

name: TheAtlantic
text: 4. Even though many disillusioned Trump supporters have flipped their loyalty since 2016, there are others whose unhappiness with the administration isn‚Äôt enough to turn their vote blue, Sarah Longwell reports. https://t.co/0Ji7KN3qTb

name: TheAtlantic
text:
5. Our staff writer Derek Thompson collected ‚Äúall of the quantitative reasons why the 2020 election is really, truly different from 2016‚Äù‚Äîincluding rectified polling mistakes, fewer undecided voters, and, of course, a global pandemic.
https://t.co/2mFrHI808o

name: TheAtlantic
text: 6. It‚Äôs not difficult to imagine the circumstances that could lead to violence tomorrow. But ‚Äúviolence isn‚Äôt preordained,‚Äù Olga Khazan writes. ‚ÄúThe best thing leaders can do to prevent violence is to accept the results of an election unequivocally.‚Äù https://t.co/qgM1WioJLS

name: TheAtlantic
text: Download our app for more election coverage: https://t.co/QKOJcmtBgO

name: TheAtlantic
text: The news media are not overblowing the pandemic‚Äôs severity ahead of Election Day. That and more in @realcpaz‚Äôs tracker of Trump‚Äôs lies: https://t.co/nm35LqjlLd

name: TheAtlantic
text: David Jay, a founder of the asexual movement, ‚Äúwanted kids and also wanted a co-parent to help him raise kids, but wasn‚Äôt interested in romantic partnership.‚Äù So he created his own three-parent household, Angela Chen reported in September. https://t.co/EiKHndWNeK

name: TheAtlantic
text: Watch: The 2020 presidential race could be remembered as a hinge point in the nation‚Äôs history. Tomorrow at 11 ET, join Atlantic senior editor @RonBrownstein, assistant editor @realcpaz, and staff writer @DkThomp for a live Election Day discussion. https://t.co/FPagXFuXsa

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Biden, along with the 3 million other Americans who wake up every morning and try to manage the neurological disability known as stuttering, is worthy of simple decency and respect when attempting to speak. Trump is incapable of offering either." https://t.co/BtwEw4RTot

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The president, freed from ever having to face voters again, would feel no need to moderate any of his many unpopular stances and impulses," writes @GrahamDavidA. "The easiest place to imagine this is at the level of staffing." https://t.co/zfrzjs1sqB

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @PaulBisceglio: "The internet is a fundamentally different place from what it was in 2016, and using it the way many people do, the president‚Äôs influence is undeniable. "

Still thinking about this excellent step back from @kait_tiffany: https://t.co/c8FlteykIi

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @JohnGHendy: Trump's Election Eve rallies feature a montage of Biden's verbal stumbles. 

Thinking today about the stutterers‚Äîplural‚Äîwho have confided in me that their feelings of shame and inadequacy once brought them to the brink of suicide. https://t.co/90PrHtVsdN

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @JeffreyGoldberg: .@JohnGHendy wrote the most important article about Joe Biden this cycle. Here is John's final pre-election statement on the subject of Trump's cruelty: 
https://t.co/yNRzaiw09Y

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @YAppelbaum: My colleague @JohnGHendy sees things with excruciating clarity. He changed my understanding of Joe Biden‚Äôs verbal stumbles with a complicated, courageous essay on the disability they share. Here, he responds to Trump‚Äôs mockery: https://t.co/CCh6FBvvPY

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @GrahamDavidA: If personnel is policy, the president's desire to fire Dr. Anthony Fauci, FBI Director Chris Wray, and others is an omen for a second Trump term https://t.co/DrHYU2SDma
